entry.title: JPK_KR_PD G/L Account mapping
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I'm currently having doubts about the way to make the mapping of G/L Accounts with financial tags and income tax tags

1/ According to our system settings, costs or revenues assigned to a single G/L Account can come from both related or unrelated parties (whereas in a standard polish solution, tow different G/L accounts would exist, according to my customer). Therefore, it seems necessary to create tow different entries in the mapping table : "G/L Account + from related entity financial tag" and "G/L Account + from other entity financial tag".

My question is : when creating the report, how will the system differentiate the "from related entities / other entities"  journal entries since they use the same G/L Account. Will the system use the "trading partner"  information to decide which mapping should be applied ? Are there other sscui settings to use for that purpose ?

2/ In the same idea, different tax codes can be assigned to transactions posted on the same G/L Account. So we have to make as many entries in the mapping table as as there are different combinations of G/L account, financial tag, and income tax tag. Is it necessary to make an additional mapping between tax codes that exist in the system and the "official" income tax tags, so that the system correctly assign the mapping to a specific journal entry ?

=> for both questions could it be usefull/necessary to create a Badi to implement dynamic determination of the tags ?

Thank you for your help,

Erwan

entry.title: Consuming DPI Service using Client Certificate Authentication
entry.content:
This blog provides a clear, step-by-step walkthrough of implementing client certificate authentication in an SAP BTP landscape.  It outlines how to configure the required artifacts, and demonstrates how to integrate them into your application. You‚Äôll also find practical guidance for testing your setup ensuring secure communication between services using mutual TLS. Whether you're new to certificate authentication or looking for a quick reference, this guide offers a concise and hands-on approach to getting it right.

  • Introduction:
  • Overview:
  • Steps:
  • Pre-Requisite :
  • Testing with direct call to DRM Endpoint
  • Testing withcustom API endpoint implemented in the backend service

Introduction:

Client Certificate Authentication is a secure method used in SAP BTP to verify the identity of an application making a request to a service. Instead of relying on passwords or OAuth tokens, the calling client presents an X.509 certificate during the TLS handshake. The service then validates this certificate against trusted authorities before allowing access.

In the SAP BTP landscape, this mechanism is commonly used when applications communicate with platform services‚Äîsuch as Destination Service, or custom apps deployed on Cloud Foundry. By configuring a certificate as a service key, destination, or trust configuration, SAP BTP ensures that only verified clients can call protected endpoints.

This method offers stronger security for machine-to-machine communication because certificates are harder to compromise, can be automatically rotated, and can be scoped strictly to the required service.

Overview:

We are using destination certificate to consume the services provided by the Data Privacy Integration (DPI) service. This certificate is used to authenticate the endpoints that we have implemented. Since we are operating in asynchronous mode, we must also send a status update to the callback endpoint after the archiving process is completed. Accordingly, the destination certificate is also used to authenticate requests to the callback endpoint.

We created a service instance of the data-privacy-integration-service using the data-privacy-internal plan. The Data Privacy Integration (DPI) service validates the certIssuer and certSubject either through the service key or through service bindings. As per the required procedure, we generated the service key accordingly. The remaining steps are outlined in the following section.

Steps:

Pre-Requisite :

  1. Create a destination certificate. Make sure to use the P12 extension while creating the certificate and choose the validity based on your requirement. Password is given to decode the certificate later. You can choose it to be empty.
    Certificate Creation on BTP
  2. The certificate will be generated with a public X.509 certificate and a private key.

    Destination Certificate on BTP
  3. Create a destination. Provide the target URL that you want to connect to. Choose ClientCertificateAuthentication from the drop down. In the Key Store Location select the certificate that you created in the previous step.

    New Destination from Scratch
  4. Destination is created with the following details.

    Destination Details
  5. To create a service key, we need to specify the parameters. The values must be obtained from the X.509 certificate created earlier.

Service Key


We tested it both via REST API Client and through a custom API implementation in one of our backend services.

Testing with direct call to DRM Endpoint

To test via REST API client, we need to get access to the certificate and key. With the export button on UI, you can excess only the public certificate. Hence, we need to use the APIs provided by cloud-sdk to access the destination certificate.

Send a GET request to https://destination-configuration.cfapps.eu12.hana.ondemand.com/destination-configuration/v1/subaccountCertificates

Choose OAuth and Client Credentials in Auth section
Obtain the credentials from the service key of destination-service service instance.
Accessing Destination Certificates created in BTP SubaccountThe response body will have the following format.

{
 {
    ‚ÄúName‚Äù: ‚Äútrial.p12‚Äù,
    ‚ÄúType‚Äù: ‚ÄúCERTIfICATE‚Äù,
    ‚ÄúContent‚Äù: ‚Äú<encoded-content>‚Äù
 }
}‚Äã

Copy the content and save it in a Trial.txt file. Use the following command to decode it and save it in a cert file.

cat Trial.txt | base64 -d > Trial.p12‚Äã

Use the command to check how the decoded file looks like. You can press enter for ‚ÄúEnter Import Password:‚Äù, since we did not provide any password while creating the certificate. This should show the certificate on screen.

openssl pkcs12 -in Trial.p12 -nodes‚Äã

We need to save certificate and key into two separate files.
To save the certificate: 

openssl pkcs12 -in Trial.p12 -nodes -out TrialCert.crt -nokeys ‚Äã

To save the key: 

openssl pkcs12 -in Trial.p12 -nodes -out TrialKey.key -nocerts

There may be some sections with ‚ÄúBag Attributes‚Äù. We can manually correct both the certificate and key files by removing these sections.

Go to your REST API Client. We are using Bruno. Add the cert and key that was created in the previous steps, along with the domain of the url you want to send request to.

Adding the Certificate in Client Certificate Section
Sending Request from Bruno


Testing with custom API endpoint implemented in the backend service

To test via custom API endpoint implemented in the backend service, we need to integrate BTP Destination Service.

Bind Connectivity and Destination Services
To enable destination-based outbound communication, ensure that both the Connectivity Service and Destination Service are bound to the required subaccount. This setup is mandatory for the application to resolve destinations at runtime.

Add the Destination Service Dependency
Include the Cloud SDK destination service artifact in the project‚Äôs pom.xml. This dependency provides the APIs required to fetch destinations and manage authentication.

<dependency>
     <groupId>com.sap.cloud.sdk.cloudplatform</groupId>
     <artifactId>connectivity-destination-service</artifactId>
 </dependency>‚Äã

Fetching the Destination (Subscriber vs. Provider Context)
If the destination is maintained in the subscriber subaccount, fetching it is straightforward because the application already runs in the subscriber‚Äôs tenant context:

var service = new DestinationService();
DestinationOptions options;
Try<Destination> destination = service.tryGetDestination("destination-name", options);

In our case, the destination ‚ÄúTRIAL_AUTH‚Äù is maintained in the provider subaccount.
Therefore, we must explicitly specify the retrieval strategy ALWAYS_PROVIDER so that the destination is fetched from the provider tenant:

DestinationService service = new DestinationService();

DestinationOptions options = DestinationOptions.builder()
      .augmentBuilder(DestinationServiceOptionsAugmenter
      .augmenter()     
      .retrievalStrategy(DestinationServiceRetrievalStrategy.ALWAYS_PROVIDER))
      .build();

Try<Destination> destinationTry = service.tryGetDestination(‚ÄúTRIAL_AUTH‚Äù, options);
Destination destination = destinationTry.get();

Create and Execute the HTTP Request Using the Resolved Destination
Once the destination has been resolved, retrieve the HTTP client from it.
The Cloud SDK automatically applies the authentication and configuration defined in the destination.

// Convert the destination to an HTTP destination
 HttpDestination httpDestination = destination.asHttp();
 
 // Obtain an HTTP client instance
 HttpClient client = HttpClientAccessor.getHttpClient(destination);
 
 // Create a generic HTTP request (e.g., HttpPut / HttpPost / HttpGet / tec)
 HttpRequestBase request = new HttpPut(httpDestination.getUri().toString());
 // Example: Replace with new HttpPost(...) or new HttpGet(...)or others as needed
 
 // --- Set headers (example) ---
 request.setHeader("Content-Type", "application/json");
 request.setHeader("Accept", "application/json");
 // Add any additional headers here...
 
 // --- Set payload (only applies to entity-enclosing requests like PUT/POST/others) ---
 StringEntity requestBody = new StringEntity(payload, "UTF-8");
 if (request instanceof HttpEntityEnclosingRequestBase) {
     ((HttpEntityEnclosingRequestBase) request).setEntity(requestBody);
 }
 
 // Execute the HTTP request
 HttpResponse response = client.execute(request);

To verify the custom API endpoint through a REST client, we used Bruno to trigger the backend service and validate the destination-based connectivity.  Add the cert and key (if cert-based authentication is enabled in your backend service)

Adding certificate

Sending Request from Bruno

entry.title: Link SAC and SAP DSP tenants via Formation to Schedule a SAC Story Based on SAP DSP Live Connection
entry.content:
Create a Formation to Integrate with SAP Analytics Cloud

Prerequisites

  • You are an SAP global account administrator, or you are a system landscape administrator.

  • SAP Analytics Cloud can run on Hana 2.0 or HANA Cloud.

  • Both SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants must be located in the same data center and deployed in the same landscape. SAP data centers are not in the scope.

  • Both SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants must use the same identity provider (IdP) and the same subject name identifier.

  • Ensure the relevant SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants or systems in your landscape are available to be integrated in a formation.

  • Context

    A formation is created in SAP BTP cockpit in the System Landscape section of your global account. The formation identifies the systems that can connect with your SAP Analytics Cloud tenant.

    Formations enable the automated integration between a set of your provisioned SAP systems.

    Procedure

    1. In the SAP BTP cockpit System Landscape  Systems page, browse the systems in your customer system landscape.
      Every SAP Analytics Cloud system and SAP Datasphere system you are going to include in this formation must not be apart of another formation. The system landscape features auto-discovered systems in the list.
      • Note

        if a given system is missing on the Systems page, it may be associated with a different customer ID on the SAP BTP global account you're working in. In this case you need to add the system manually, and then register it. For more information, see Adding, Registering, and Deregistering Systems.

    2. Go to System Landscape   Formations. Select Create Formation.
      1. In the General Information step, enter a descriptive formation name.
      2. In the Formation Type drop-down menu, select Integration with SAP Analytics Cloud.
    3. Select Next Step.
    4. In the Include Systems step, select the SAP Datasphere tenant and SAP Analytics Cloud tenant you want to link with.
    5. Select Next Step.
    6. Review your selections and create the formation.

    Results

    The formation appears under your list of formations and a Ready success message is shown.

    Delete a Formation in SAP BTP Cockpit

    Context

    When you delete a formation, the following happens. Both SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants will be excluded from the formation. Then, the subaccount is unassigned. Finally, the SAP Analytics Cloud formation is removed from the Formations page completely.

    Procedure

    1. In the SAP BTP cockpit go to System Landscape  Formations.
    2. Select the formation of SAP Analytics Cloud that you want to remove.
    3. Select Delete at the top-right of the formation.

    Recreation of Formation

    When formation is recreated the scheduling feature will be enabled again. The functionalities will continue to work as they were before the deletion. For scheduling, UCL formation will only provide enablement of tunneled connections.

    As a next step to create Tunnel connection and perform scheduling of SAC story based on DSP live connectivity please follow the help document. 

    https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ANALYTICS_CLOUD/18850a0e13944f53aa8a8b7c094ea29e/1c4c615f5d7f4b78a5ae681759a55650.html?version=2025.23

Hello everyone, 

I have been working on making my reports responsive recently, and since the last update, I encounter a little issue, which I wanted to share with you, in order to have more information about it, or if it is not intended, simply report that this exists.

When you are in the builder panel of your section, working to adapt the size of your widget, you have the possibility to switch from 'Free' to 'Auto-Flow'. 

My issue comes up when you want to add a widget in the 'Widget Width' or 'Height' section. In free mode, you can 'Add widget', and then you have a Drop-down panel to choose the widget you wish to adapt.  And as long as I remember, it always worked like this. 

 

 

But now, when I switch to Auto-flow, the drop-down still exists, but does not allow me to select other widgets, so I have to add all my widgets first, and then adapt the sizes.

 

 

I don't know if this was intended, but I find it a bit annoying since the report updates only when all fields are filled in.

Let me know if you face the same problem, and if anyone has information about it, I would be really interested !

Have a nice day,

Julien Dorffer

entry.title: Scheduling SAP Analytics Cloud Stories Based on SAP Datasphere Live Connections
entry.content:
Overview

(Available Starting QRC4 2025)

Scheduled publications are an important feature in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), enabling organizations to distribute stories at regular intervals for offline access over email email delivery.

As SAP Datasphere continues to be the strategic data foundation for SAP customers, many organizations rely extensively on live connections between SAC and Datasphere. Starting with SAP Analytics Cloud QRC4 2025, customers can now schedule publications for stories built on SAP Datasphere live connections.

This capability is supported for:

  • SAP Analytics cloud and SAP Datasphere on BDC Tenant
  • Standalone (non-BDC) SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere Tenant

Prerequisites

To schedule a story based on a Datasphere live connection, the story must use an SAP Datasphere Tunnel Connection.

Creating a Datasphere Tunnel Connection

A Tunnel Connection can be created only when SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants are ‚Äúdeep linked.‚Äù Deep linking ensures seamless authentication, metadata access, and cross-system operations.

Deep linking configurations:

  • Option 1 ‚Äî In BDC tenant where SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants are linked via BDC formation (Recommended)
  • Option 2 ‚Äî In SAP Analytics Cloud tenant and SAP Datasphere tenant (Non BDC) are linked via UCL formation.  (Recommended) - Refer to blog Link SAC and SAP DSP tenants via Formation to Schedule a SAC Story Based on SAP DSP Live Connection 
  • Option 3 ‚Äî SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere Tenant are linked for seamless planning as below 

     

Once any one of the above configurations is done, In SAP Analytics Cloud tenant, you can create a SAP Datasphere Tunnel connection using below step

  • From the side navigation, choose Connections  
  • Click Add + Connection
  • Expand Connect to Live Data and select SAP Datasphere.
  • In the dialog, enter a name and description for your connection.
  • From the Connection Type drop-down list, select Tunnel
    • Tunnel connection type is mandatory if you plan to use this Scheduled Publications using the Datasphere Live connection.
    • For tunnel connections, ensure both SAC and Datasphere users use the same Identity Provider (IdP)

Note: In QRC4.2025, you have an option to create new Tunnel connection, however, you will not be able to convert existing SAP Datasphere Direct connection to Tunnel connection. However, if you are on Fast track tenant and SAP Analytics Cloud version 2025.23 or beyond then you can edit Direct connection to Tunnel Connection. If you are on QRC tenant, then this will be available in QRC1.2026

 

Scheduling a Story Based on a Datasphere Live Connection

Once the Tunnel Connection is created and used in the story, it can be scheduled like any other SAC story, with support for email distribution, CSV/Excel/PDF/PowerPoint output, recurrence, dynamic time filters, and personalization.

Conclusion

Starting QRC4 2025, this enhancement supports Scheduling Publication of SAP Analytics Cloud story capabilities for customers using SAP Datasphere with SAP Analytics Cloud.

Hi GririRaaj,

Actually, even though SAC is a public cloud service offering, there are two options that you can opt in for SAC: Public Tenant or Private Tenant. Both of them are considered public cloud (since you can access over the internet), however private tenant ensures that data will run on a specific isolated machine for only that customer.

you can also check : https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/sap-analytics-cloud-usage-of-private-tenant/qaq-p/12339313#:~:text=A%20SAP%20Analytics%20Cloud%20(SAC)%20private%20tenant,computing%20resource%20(CPU%20and%20Memory)%20becoming%20short

entry.title: First Steps with Joule Skill (Advanced): Request Badges for Multiple Users with Automation
entry.content:
It has been about three months since Joule Studio was released.
Several tutorials are already available on SAP Tutorials, and the community is slowly getting more active.  And, I think many people still wonder: ‚ÄúWhat can we really do with Joule Studio?‚Äù„ÄÇ

One of the tutorials is ‚ÄúBuild Your First Joule Skill in Joule Studio.‚Äù In this tutorial, you create two Actions, Action to read data from an S/4 mock system and Action to create a badge. Then you use these Actions in a Joule Skill.

In this tutorial, you will create an action project for accessing business partner information from an OData service representing an SAP system. You will also create an action project for creating a badge request via an OData service representing a third-party system.

This tutorial is very good and easy to learn how to make Joule Skill. However, one of my colleagues asked me a question:

‚ÄúWhat if we want to send badge requests for multiple users at once?‚Äù

With the tutorial as it is, you need to send a request to Joule one user at a time.

So in this blog, we will change the scenario and send badge requests for multiple users in one go.

There is one problem. In Joule Skill, we do not have loop control function like "Go to Step" in Process, "forEach" in Automation. Because of this, it is difficult to call Business Partner GET and Badge Create POST again and again inside Joule Skill only.

To solve this, we will use Automation inside Joule Skill. This is the final flow:

„ÄÄ

 

Step1 - Create a Skeleton Joule Skill

A Joule Skill can call Automaton (or Process). In this scenario, we will send a list of Business Partner Ids from the Joule Skill to the Automation. However, in the Joule Skill, the input parameter on trigger phase does not have a data type setting. It is treated as String only.

So, on the Joule side, Joule will enter IDs as one comma-separated string like "AAAA, BBBB". And, inside the Automation, we will convert this String to a List of String. In the Joule Skill, we define the input parameter like:

  • Inputs Name: BusinessPartnerList
  •  Description: a list of BusinessPartner ID like "AAAA, BBBB"

(In the original tutorial, there are some other input parameters. To keep this blog simple, I will not use them here.)

 

Step2 - Create the Automation

Next, we create an Automation. Leave the Joule Skill editor, and go to SAP Build Lobby to create a new Automation project.

If you have not se up the Desktop Agent yet, plz follow this tutorial:
Install and Set Up Desktop Agent 3

At the beginning of the Automation, we use a Custom Script to convert the input String to a List of String. The image is like the following Javascript:

function parseIds(rawIds) {
  if (typeof rawIds !== "string") {
    throw new Error("rawIds must be a string like 'AAA, BBBB'.");
  }

  const ids = rawIds
    .split(",")
    .map(s => s.trim())
    .filter(Boolean);

  if (ids.length === 0) {
    throw new Error("No valid IDs found. Expected something like 'AAA, BBBB'.");
  }

  return ids;
}

With this, we can use forEach in the next step and process each ID one by one.

Next, open Project Properties(top-right gear icon), and select Manage Dependencies -> Add an Action Project Dependency. Here, add the two Action Projects from the original tutorial, Business Partner GET and Badge Create POST. 

Now we build the flow like this:

  1. Convert the input String to a List by the "String to List" Custom Script
  2. Use forEach to take one ID at a time
  3. Call the Action Get data from BusinessPartner API
  4. Call the Action Create Badge using the result

Finally, in Project Properties -> Attributes, connect the Agent attribute that you created when you set up the Agent.

When everything is ready, click Release -> Deploy. Then, to use this Automation from Joule Skill, go to the Lobby, open the correct version and click Publish to Library.

 

3. Use the Automation inside the Joule Skill

Go back to your Joule Skill, and add a Run Automation step. First, click Browse All Automations and select the Automation you just created.

Next, map the Joule Skill input parameter Business PartnerList to the Automation input.

After that, add a Send Message node in the next step. 

When the flow is ready, click Release -> Deploy for the Joule Skill as well.

 

4. Test the scenario

As I mentioned before, an Automation needs an Agent (and in the correct, "Agent" is not an AI Agent üòÄ). When we run an Automation from inside a Joule Skill, we must tell Joule which Agent to use.

Open Control Tower -> Environments, and go to the environment where your Automation and Joule Skill are deployed. In Agent Management, add the target Agent to that environment.

On your local PC, open the Desktop Agent settings and check that Agent Mode is Unattended.

In the environment screen, you will see a tab named ‚ÄúJoule‚Äù on the far right. Check the version of the Joule Skill you created, and click Launch to open Joule.

Now, try to send a prompt to test the Skill.

You can see that a badge request is created for each ID!!

Internally, the Automation is just running a forEach loop, so the same design works for both a single request and multiple requests in one run. In the future, if Joule Skills support file upload, we may also be able to read IDs from a file and send a large number of badge requests in bulk.

 

Conclusion

What do you think? With this approach, we can extend a Joule Skill by using our existing knowledge of SAP Build Process Automation. The way we design the Automation is almost the same as in other SBPA use cases. We simply call it from Joule.

On the other hand, there are still some gaps:

  • Joule Skill does not have flexible flow control like Go to Step
  • We cannot directly map Automation output to Joule Skill variables yet (SAP Help says there is an Output tab, but in my current environment I cannot see it.) 

Even with these limits, combining Joule Studio and SBPA already gives us many options. I am very excited to see how Joule Studio will grow in future updates!!!!

 

The CoE Japan team runs PoCs and scenario validations not only for Joule Studio, but also for many other SAP products. Through technical validations, architecture discussions, and sharing best practices, we support our customers and partners in getting more value from SAP from a technical point of view.

If you are thinking: ‚ÄúCan we do something like this with Joule or SAP Build?‚Äù please feel free to contact the CoE Japan team.

entry.title: Re: Executing Dynamic SQL from a Parameterized View in SAP Datasphere
entry.content: Challenges Script Operators in Dataflows Script Operators in Dataflows cannot execute arbitrary SQL. Python Script Operators in Dataflows only process DataFrames from upstream sources. Parameterized views cannot be called directly, nor can SQL statements be executed dynamically via sql.execute_query inside a Script Operator. Script Operators accept only Materialized tables, or Non-parameterized views. Direct use of a parameterized view as a source in Dataflows is not supported. External Python Script Even when SQL execution is performed externally (e.g., via Python scripts connected to HANA), results cannot be written back into Datasphere UI due to privilege restrictions. The GENERATED_SQL column can be fetched and executed externally using Python scripts.But the technical user has only SELECT privileges, cannot perform INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE on space-owned tables. Limitations: Results cannot be returned automatically to Datasphere without write access. Exporting results as CSV and manually uploading them is possible, but this is not automated. Stored Procedure in HANA DB The stored procedure is created to execute SQL statements dynamically and write results to the table residing in FSDM_DEMO space. When executed as user DWCDBUSER#MAYURANALAWADE, it fails with insufficient privileges error. Database User Groups: Created DUGs, but the group schema does not have read/write access to DQ_RESULTS which resides in FSDM_DEMO schema. SQL View in SAP Datasphere SAP Datasphere / HANA does not allow a SQL view to execute dynamic SQL stored in a column. A SQL view is static: it can select, join, filter, aggregate, etc., but it cannot run SQL statements stored as text in a column. There is no ‚Äúexecute this column as SQL‚Äù feature inside a view. Table Function in SAP Datasphere Table Functions cannot execute dynamic SQL. There is no replacement for EXECUTE IMMEDIATE in Table Functions.

entry.title: AI-Assisted User Learning & Change Management ‚Äì HPFA Idea Project
entry.content:
Anyone who has been part of an SAP project knows this feeling: the system is ready, the processes are solid‚Ä¶ but getting everyone trained and confident takes far more time than expected. Teams can spend weeks analysing process changes, figuring out who needs what training, and then writing pages and pages of content from scratch. It‚Äôs slow, expensive, and honestly, quite exhausting for everyone involved.

This is exactly the pain point our team wanted to tackle.

Over the past months, we have been working on AI-assisted user learning and change management ‚Äî a simple idea with a big impact. Instead of manually rebuilding training from zero for every project, the app reads SAP Signavio, Cloud ALM and other process data and turns it into clear, role-based training content automatically. In early pilots, tasks that used to take 10 days could be done in a single day. And the content stays consistent and aligned with SAP Best Practices.

The goal is pretty straightforward:
to help people learn faster, reduce project stress, and make adoption feel smooth instead of overwhelming.

This project is now part of the Hasso Plattner Founders‚Äô Award ‚Äì Scaling Innovation challenge, and we‚Äôre honestly excited (and a little proud) to share it with the SAP community. The award focuses on ideas that bring real, long-term value to customers and to SAP ‚Äî and we believe this one really does.

If you feel the same, it would mean a lot to us if you could support the idea with a quick boost.
Every click helps the project get more visibility, and it motivates the team to keep pushing the innovation further.

*** [Click here to boost the Idea Project] *** 
(Your support genuinely makes a difference.)

And a big thank you to everyone who already tested, challenged, or encouraged us along the way. This project grew because of real collaboration, curiosity, and a shared wish to make SAP learning easier for people everywhere.

Let‚Äôs make change a bit lighter ; and a lot more human.

entry.title: Re: CrystalReportViewer text field is grow to whole row....
entry.content:
Original Comment:

Hi @DON,, Thanks for you reply. I try set printer to any default printer. and Enable Dissociate Formatting in Page Setup. but not worked. I still got overlapping description.

Also Registry key not found in my side:

I try to find registry in WOW6432Node same not found

NOTE: I think this is should be treated as Bug. in Web version of Crystal Reports.

I think there's no way except I try programmatically change Can Grow to make forcibly true. and lines = 1? I mean set that for non-can grow text fields. Don't have much knowledge to do programmatically.  But this issue should treated as Bug in Crystal Web Viewer.

Regards.

 

Edit1 ) I updated to latest CR SP38. Same issue.

Edit 3) 2025-11-20 

The only working method that you mentioned is dynamically use EnableCanGrow from code. But I also can't set MaximumNumberOfLines from C# code.

foreach(FieldObject obj in doc.ReportDefinition.ReportObjects.OfType<FieldObject>())
{
obj.ObjectFormat.EnableCanGrow = true;
}

Above code fix overlapping but it make it CanGrow without Maximum Number Of lines. (No C# property for that)

I mean in Web Viewer version I must set Number Of Lines to 1 with CanGrow = true. so it will be same as WinForms version (Trim remaining text)

Edit 3 (Final workaround)
The only way to show MaxNumberOfLines is to use RAS model.

        public static void FixWebCanGrowFields(this ReportDocument doc)
        {
            ISCDReportClientDocument rptClientDoc = doc.ReportClientDocument;
            foreach (CrystalDecisions.ReportAppServer.ReportDefModel.Area area in rptClientDoc.ReportDefinition.Areas)
            {
                foreach (CrystalDecisions.ReportAppServer.ReportDefModel.Section sec in area.Sections)
                {
                    foreach (CrystalDecisions.ReportAppServer.ReportDefModel.ReportObject obj in sec.ReportObjects)
                    {
                        if (obj is CrystalDecisions.ReportAppServer.ReportDefModel.FieldObject fobj)
                        {
                            if (fobj.FieldValueType == CrFieldValueTypeEnum.crFieldValueTypeStringField && fobj.Format.EnableCanGrow == false) // Only for Web Viewer :Bug Crystal
                            {
                                fobj.Format.EnableCanGrow = true;
                                fobj.FieldFormat.StringFormat.MaxNumberOfLines = 1;
                                rptClientDoc.ReportDefController.ReportObjectController.Modify(fobj, fobj);
                            }
                        }
                    }
                }
            }
        }

 Its too hard to do that!. This issue should treated as bug. I got above code running after digging so hard. 

But now the result is Ok.

entry.title: Re: Copy of movement type config is not editable in S4 HA...
entry.content:
Good day @Sindhu_Ravi 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Implementing Routines to Prevent Creation of Duplicate MM IDocs, Consumption Values, Forecast Consumption

The greying out effects you experience is because movement type configuration is locked in public cloud. Due to the clean-core principle in public cloud, the system doesn't allow you to configure changes (e.g., copying or creating new movement types, editing consumption posting, etc.). Therefore you cannot change movement type 291‚Äôs consumption posting from R --> blank and you cannot modify its MRP/Forecast behaviour.

A clean-core workaround option you can consider in achieving your functional requirement to exclude 291 from forecast consumption is as follows:

You can build your own CDS View where you include only 601 and 641. Open the CDS view App.

Create a new view. Ensure you choose a standard scenario. You can name it CONSUMPTIONANALYSIS

Then select a data source. Ensure you use a released inventory CDS view such as I_MaterialDocumentItem or I_InventoryConsumption (if available in you scope)

Thereafter, in the filters section, add MovementType IN (601, 641) and MovementType NOT IN (291). Or you can manually select only the needed ones in the where clause.

You can either run a check (log provides details) or you publish directly.

You can then add fields you require

Finally, publish and that gives you a custom report that will automatically exclude 291 from all forecast or consumption calculations.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to add output tax line item in customer master data
entry.content:
Hi Chen,

in S/4HANA Public Cloud, this is currently not possible. You can create a custom tax condition type (as you already did), but you cannot maintain specific tax classifications for this tax condition type. For a custom condition type only the same tax classifications as for the standard pre-delivered condition type of the respective departure country can be maintained. During pricing, the maintained tax classifications of the standard pre-delivered tax condition type will be used. Hence, you can adjust the tax classifications of TTX1 for customer and material in your case according to your business requirements.

Kind regards,

Uwe

entry.title: Re: Automating Message Retries in SAP CPI with the Data Store Channel
entry.content:
@varun1

As mentioned in the blog, you‚Äôll still need to re-invoke the iFlow when an error occurs. Instead of re-executing the entire iFlow, call only the local process where the error happened. To enable this, save the payload immediately before the error point and architect the iFlow as a set of smaller local processes where errors can occur. For each local process, persist a parameter that indicates the exact failure location; pass that parameter to the exception subprocess so it knows where to resume or handle the error.

Note: I haven‚Äôt implemented this logic yet  this is a proposed design approach I‚Äôm considering

How to make 'Tax code' field mandatory in purchase order

entry.title: Re: we want to apply tax code is mandatory for PO creation .
entry.content:
Hi,

You can use BAdI MM_PUR_S4_PO_FLDCNTRL_SIMPLE to modify the properties of specific fields that appear on the user interface of the apps:

  • Manage Purchase Orders on item level in the section Process Control
  • Create Purchase Order - Advanced on item level on the tabs Delivery and Invoice.

The SAP GUI transactions ME21N, ME22N, ME23N are also affected by this
BAdI.
You can make the fields hidden, read-only, mandatory, or optional as per
your requirements.

Using the BAdI you can change the field control properties for the TAXCODE field.

If user's BAdI implementation defines the status of a field as 'Mandatory' that SAP has defined as 'Optional', the system does not perform a check and does not output an error message.

The user can implement the BAdI Check of Purchase Order Before Saving (BD_MMPUR_FINAL_CHECK_PO) to perform their own checks and to output the corresponding error messages.

Refer to:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003268822

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003468887

Best regards,

SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Error When Logging into CBC
entry.content:
Dear @naoakisaruyama,

This error is coming from SAP Cloud Identity Services Identity Authentication (IAS), not directly from CBC itself.

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/authorization-and-trust-management-service/authorization-and-trust-management/token-retrieval-fails-with-status-code-401

Answer 1

Every user have to click that link, or can an administrator fix it?

  • No, this is not something that must be initialized by each user.
  • If the message keeps appearing, it should be fixed once, centrally in IAS (or by SAP for a partner demo tenant).

What an IAS administrator would normally do in a customer-owned tenant:

  1. Log on to the IAS administrator console
  2. Open the application that represents CBC
  3. Check:
    • Default Identity Provider for the application
    • Any configured Login Hint parameter
  4. Make sure the origin key that is passed in login_hint (or configured as xsuaa.origin / Default IdP) matches an existing, active IdP in IAS
  5. Save / activate.

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/authenticating-identity-provider-for-application

Once this is corrected:

  • All users will be routed to the right IdP automatically again.
  • The red box with origin provided in the login hint is invalid disappears for everyone no need for each user to click anything.

In a partner demo environment

For a partner demo Public Cloud system, IAS and CBC are usually managed by SAP (or by your partner admin, not by end-users). In that case:

  • You normally don‚Äôt have the IAS admin role for that tenant
  • If the error persists, the right approach is to open an SAP support incident (component BC-IAM-IDS) and attach your screenshot and CBC URL

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/getting-support?version=Cloud

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/53e36b5493804bcdb3f6f14de8b487dd/b60dd89024994573873a231502d4ddd4.html1

Answer 2

It‚Äôs purely an authentication routing problem, not a CBC data problem.

Typical impact:

  • You may not get automatic SSO into CBC, instead you see the blue IAS page with the warning and must pick an IdP/link
  • Until you do that, you cannot access CBC in that browser session.

What is not affected:

  • CBC projects, configuration activities, transports, Cloud configuration etc. are untouched this is before you even reach CBC
  • Your Public Cloud system login itself usually uses a different IAS application and can work fine at the same time

Potentially affected in more complex landscapes:

  • Any other apps that reuse the same IAS application and the same invalid origin could show the same message or fail automated token requests with origin provided in login_hint does not match an active Identity Provider

For your scenario (partner demo CBC):

  • It is almost certainly limited to the CBC login and does not corrupt or change any CBC or Public Cloud configuration.

Answer 3

Technically, IAS is evaluating an OAuth/SAML request that contains a login_hint with an origin field (something like {"origin":"someIdPKey"}), and:

  • that origin key does not exist,
  • or exists but is disabled for that application,
  • or was changed/renamed in IAS while the application still uses the old value

Typical concrete triggers:

  1. Change in IAS configuration
    • Someone modified the IdP setup (renamed an origin key, disabled a corporate IdP, changed default IdP, adjusted login-hint rules) for the CBC application.
  2. System refresh / new tenant / partner demo housekeeping
    • SAP or the landscape owner refreshed or re-provisioned the partner demo and the IAS‚ÄìCBC trust configuration changed slightly.
    • The link you use to go from Public Cloud to CBC still contains a login_hint for the previous IdP origin.

When you manually click ayge3zpo2.accounts.cloud.sap:

  • You bypass the invalid login_hint routing and directly choose a valid IdP (the local IAS user store).
  • IAS authenticates you, creates a session, and the CBC call then succeeds.

So the trigger is platform-level identity configuration, not anything you did in CBC or Public Cloud customizing.

Summary and practically recommend for you

Since this is a partner demo Public Cloud environment:

  1. If the error was only once and now you get SSO into CBC without seeing that screen again, you can treat it as a one-off IAS routing glitch.
  2. If it keeps happening
    • Collect:
      • CBC URL,
      • timestamp,
      • screenshot with the error.
    • Raise an incident for BC-IAM-IDS (SAP Cloud Identity Services Identity Authentication), mention that CBC login for your Public Cloud partner demo shows: The origin provided in the login hint is invalid
    • Ask them to check the IdP origin / login_hint configuration for the CBC application in your IAS tenant.

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Limitations when automating Maintenance Plan Creation in SAP Sales Cloud
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

We are currently working on a development that should automatically create Maintenance Plans in SAP Sales Cloud, 

Solution Version 2511.01.0003, based on a specific trigger. However, we have identified two major issues.

1. No programmatic access to key Maintenance Plan fields (Plan Definition tab)

We have found that:

  • The Plan Definition structure (ConditionGroup) in the Maintenance Plan is read-only.
  • The fields that define the plan frequency - specifically the Condition and Value fields- cannot be written or modified via SDK, nor via publicly available APIs:

This means that even though a Maintenance Plan object can theoretically be created via development, it would be incomplete, since the essential scheduling parameters cannot be filled programmatically.

We would like to know:

  • Is there any SAP-supported way to enable write access to this structure?

  • Is there an alternative API or workaround that SAP recommends? 

  • If not currently available, can SAP consider enabling write access to this object in the Public Solution Model?

 

2. Data Workbench Template also does not allow uploading scheduling values

We tried loading Maintenance Plans using Data Workbench, but the upload template also doesn't allow filling in the required frequency values. The template only allows fields like:

  • Schedule Type
  • Schedule Condition

But there is no way to populate the ‚ÄúValue‚Äù and ‚ÄúUnit‚Äù fields of the Plan Definition, even though these are mandatory for a complete and usable Maintenance Plan.

This leads to a key question:

  • How can SAP provide mass upload functionality for Maintenance Plans in Data Workbench if the upload template does not include the fields required to define the plan frequency?

Summarizing, we are blocked because:

  • We cannot set scheduling values programmatically (SDK or APIs).

  • We cannot load them via Data Workbench either.

  • Without these values, Maintenance Plans cannot generate Tickets automatically ‚Äî which is the fundamental purpose of the object.

Any guidance from SAP experts or product owners would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Re: SAP Build Process Automation ‚Äì Configuring Microsoft 365 email provider for SMTP mail destinatio
entry.content:
Hello @vincent00 ,

Thank you for reaching out. Here are a few things to check:

1. Verify the destination name: The destination must be named exactly: sap_process_automation_mail (case-sensitive).

2. Allow time for synchronization: After creating or modifying a destination in the BTP Cockpit, there's a brief synchronization period with your SAP Build Process Automation tenant. This typically takes only a few seconds, but please allow up to a minute for the destination to appear.

3. Confirm the destination location: Ensure the destination was created in the same subaccount as your SAP Build Process Automation tenant.

If the destination still doesn't appear after verifying these points, I'll need access to tenant-specific information and logs to investigate further. Please open a support ticket so our team can access your tenant details and provide more detailed assistance.

Best regards,

Erwan

entry.title: SAP PAPM - the role of business calculation engine in a business steering
entry.content:
Picture 1. End-to-end profitability and performance management

MOTIVATION

In today's fast-paced business world, the ability to effectively steer and lead an organization is fundamental for achieving strategic goals and maintaining a competitive edge. A key success criterion is the capacity to fully harness and derive value from organizational data. Many companies struggle with data problems, such as fragmented information, outdated systems, and the super important task of preparing data for emerging technologies like AI. Recognizing these challenges, we are excited to introduce a blog series dedicated to showcasing the substantial business value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in the context of planning and analytics.

The motivation behind this initiative is to provide a comprehensive exploration of how SAP BDC capabilities as essential instruments, facilitating robust strategic alignment and guiding effective decision-making processes across diverse organizational requirements. We aim to illustrate how SAP BDC, equipped with powerful data management, planning, analytics and innovative AI capabilities, empowers organizations with enhanced business steering agility by providing real-time insights, streamlined data management, and automated decision support ‚Äì going from insights to action, helps mainly leaders guide their businesses with precision.

Our blog series will provide valuable insights for decision-makers seeking to harness SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to enhance operational efficiency, optimize resource allocation, and achieve long-term objectives. By featuring detailed planning & analytics topics, the series will illustrate the transformative impact of SAP BDC in addressing the operational complexities of today‚Äôs business environment. This first introductory blog post will spotlight the strategic advantages of SAP BDC, particularly in the context of Business Steering, setting the stage for a deeper exploration of its benefits throughout the blog series.

There are several blog posts in the series that will cover advantages of SAP BDC in the context of business steering, so please stay tuned for the upcoming blogs:

  1. The Value of SAP BDC in the context of business steering 
  2.  Planning & Analytics is an essential part of SAP BDC  
  3. Key Planning & Analytics components of SAP BDC 
  4. Is AI going to ‚Äúretire‚Äù a dashboard?
  5. Simulations, a game changer in today‚Äôs volatile world
  6. Extend existing planning scenarios of SAP BPC/BW-IP in SAP BDC 
  7. Real-time steering with LIVE planning
  8. SAP PaPM - The role of business calculation engine in business steering (THIS BLOG POST)
  9. Self ‚Äì service analytics and real time business steering
  10. Business steering powered by AI agents
  11. Leverage data products in the context of planning & forecasting
  12. Introducing AI/ML capabilities by SAP Databricks

INTRODUCTION

In today‚Äôs fast-paced business environment, enterprises must be flexible and adaptable to evolving market conditions and customer expectations. As a result, companies are developing strategies focused on innovation, digital transformation, and sustainable growth. However, when it comes to execution, the benefits of these strategic initiatives often fall short of expectations.

Why the Gap?

Several factors contribute to the disconnect between strategy and execution:

  • Insufficient analysis and adaptation to business changes, making strategies difficult to execute in real-world conditions.
  • Weak integration between financial and operational models, leading to misaligned decisions.
  • Lack of trust in the numbers due to data silos and overly complex reporting models.
  • Poor visibility into root causes of performance, whether underperformance or overachievement.

This is where the concept of Enterprise Performance Management (EPM) becomes critical. EPM serves as the bridge between strategic goals and day-to-day execution. SAP offers a comprehensive, end-to-end EPM framework that spans planning, consolidation, tax, and sustainability management.

Despite advancements, organizations still face hurdles in their EPM processes, that are highly connected to the reasons for the gap between strategy and execution:

  • New regulations and market dynamics
  • Data  silos and disconnected processes
  • Limited business context in performance reporting

To address these, companies increasingly need a business semantics calculation engine as an important part of their EPM framework ‚Äîa solution that connects transactional and planning data to management reporting in real time. Such an engine should enable:

  • Business-user-driven modeling through a no-code/low-code environment
  • Integration of business semantics (e.g., cost allocations, profitability logic) into real-time calculations, powered by solutions like SAP Business Data Cloud
  • Simulation and scenario analysis without IT dependency

Let‚Äôs explore how a business semantics calculation engine can bring value across different scenarios not only for actuals, but also for planning data:

  • Regulatory reporting: Ensure compliance with traceable, rule-based calculations.
  • Profitability analysis: Evaluate performance by customer segment, region, channel, or product line.
  • Bill of Materials (BOM) simulation and explosion: Assess the impact of changing prices or quantities on semi-finished and final products.
  • Operational transfer pricing: Maintain compliance and transparency in cross-border pricing models.
  • Group cost calculations: Enable unified and transparent cost modeling across entities.

For instance, in a BOM simulation, users can assess how price or quantity changes at the component level affect the cost of the final product. This often involves recursive, high-volume calculations. By using SAP S/4HANA for transactional data, enriching it with SAP Profitability and Performance Management (SAP PaPM), and feeding the results into SAP Analytics Cloud, businesses can maintain full transparency, auditability, and planning granularity.

Another example: planned profitability calculations at the SKU level. While this level of detail may be unnecessary in the core budgeting process, it's critical for management reporting. Rather than overburdening the core planning system, businesses can offload these complex calculations to a dedicated engine and integrate the results seamlessly.

Last but not the least example to illustrate the need in business calculation engine is a group costing calculation. Let's say the company has many intercompany relationships, products and services are going through various steps between companies in this process. SAP PAPM delivers real-time insights into group margin, through segmented profit and loss reports according to key transfer pricing dimensions, providing needed data to manage and analyze tax costs and revenues, markups and markup costs, production and services costs and third-party revenues.

Benefits of Embedding a Calculation Engine into the Planning Process

  • Automate complex allocations and business logic
  • Ensure full transparency and auditability
  • Enable granular planning and analysis‚Äîby customer, product, channel, etc.
  • Increase compliance by following new regulations

From the business user‚Äôs perspective, this process should be seamless. As a planner, you simply run the calculation and see results immediately integrated into your planning reports. This is precisely the kind of user-centric experience enabled by the SAP EPM framework‚Äîcombining SAP S/4HANA, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Profitability and Performance Management (SAP PaPM).

Picture 2. Detailed Profitability analysis powered by SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP PAPM

WHAT IS SAP PAPM? 

SAP PaPM Cloud is a no-code calculation engine that empowers business users to model and execute complex logic without IT intervention. It processes large data volumes at high speed and supports a wide range of EPM scenarios.

Key capabilities include:

  • Extending standardized processes in SAP S/4HANA with custom logic and allocations
  • Enabling business users to model complex rules without coding
  • Processing massive data sets in-memory via SAP HANA
  • Integrating data from SAP and non-SAP sources, hosted on SAP Business Data Cloud
  • Creating financial documents, postings to general or group ledger, and more in SAP S/4HANA enabling an end-to-end process, and not just running as a disconnected calculation engine
  • Ensuring full traceability from results to source data

Picture 3. SAP Profitability and Performance Management

SAP PAPM and SAP BUSINESS DATA CLOUD

SAP PAPM can on top of BDC, in this case data persistency and processing happens on the SAP Datasphere level in SAP BDC. With SAP BDC Data products we can ensure context-rich data from SAP and non- SAP sources being available for PAPM calculations, building a foundation for detailed transparent analysis and also providing even more data for AI-powered insights.  Another benefit of placing SAP PAPM on top of SAP BDC is that with SAC being also part of the platform, we can really ensure end-to-end EPM processes without data replication, leveraging seamless planning and when needed extending calculations with SAP PAPM engine to achieve even greater transparency and performance.  Ream more about BDC components in our previous blog "Key Planning & Analytics components of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC)"

Picture 4. SAP Business Data Cloud components

Let‚Äôs take a look at the data flow for a corporate profitability analysis within an SAP landscape.
The initial data originates in the transactional system or system of record, SAP S/4HANA. While S/4HANA already provides capabilities for cost calculation and allocation, we can further enrich this data with performance results and details‚Äîsuch as customer segment, region, channel, or product line‚Äîand incorporate simulations.

To achieve this, we introduce an additional BDC-based layer that leverages BDC data products and SAP Datasphere to connect to S/4HANA, as well as other potential data sources and prepare the data. SAP PaPM then performs the calculations, and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) visualizes the results and provides a planning-process framework for end users.

Picture 5. Corporate profitability analysis with SAP solutions

Conclusion

A business semantics calculation engine is a powerful tool in enhancing the efficiency and effectiveness of EPM processes. Whether it‚Äôs for tax, transfer pricing, profitability modelling, or planning enhancements, SAP Profitability and Performance Management plays an important role in bridging the gap between transactional data and reporting requirements.

By embedding SAP PaPM within your EPM architecture, you can equip business users to act even faster, have greater insights, and align execution more closely with strategic intent. SAP Business Data cloud will provide a proven semantically reach data foundation and AI tools to simplify analysis, we will be giving more detailed examples in our next articles. 

Looking to take the next step? Connect with your SAP representative to register for an SAP BDC Discovery Workshop.
To expand your expertise in SAP PaPM, consider exploring the related blog series published within the SAP Community  and stay tuned for more.

entry.title: Re: ABAP Proxy generation support with SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Hi @radhika_javvaji , @KevinSong 

My issue is now resolved. The proxy objects were there but under a different bucket. I followed steps below:

1- Run t-code SPROXY.

2- Goto menu Utilities --> Settings

3- Scroll to the tab Proxy Generation and change the Enterprise Service Browser setting to "D Enterprise Service Browser"

4- Back out and re-run SPROXY. 

5- Follow node Source --> ESR --> SWCs and you will see your custom integration packages there.

Note:- Choose Re-usable option while migrating your SAP PO interfaces to integration suite. Otherwise, no objects will be created in the backend.

Hope it helps.

Regards,

Kamran
